articles.headline: Corporations Open Up About Political Spending
articles.snippet: With companies increasing their disclosures about contributions, perhaps campaign finance reformers should turn their attention elsewhere.
articles.abstract: With companies increasing their disclosures about contributions, perhaps campaign finance reformers should turn their attention elsewhere.
articles.lead_paragraph: In November 1999, Time Warner swore off “soft money” contributions to political campaigns. At the time, it might have seemed like a mistake. The company was about to join with America Online in a deal that would require approval from federal regulators. Yet Gerald M. Levin, Time Warner’s chairman, argued that soft money not only distorted American politics, it sullied the company as well.

articles.headline: Court Upholds Texas Limits on Abortions
articles.snippet: A federal appellate court upheld some of the toughest provisions of a Texas law, putting more than a dozen abortion clinics at risk of permanently shutting.
articles.abstract: A federal appellate court upheld some of the toughest provisions of a Texas law, putting more than a dozen abortion clinics at risk of permanently shutting.
articles.lead_paragraph: WACO, Tex. — A federal appellate court upheld some of the toughest provisions of a Texas abortion law on Tuesday, putting about half of the state’s remaining abortion clinics at risk of permanently shutting their doors and leaving the nation’s second-most populous state with fewer than a dozen clinics across its more than 267,000 square miles. There were 41 when the law was passed.
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez and Erik Eckholm

articles.headline: Andrew Lack Returns to NBC News Amid Turmoil
articles.snippet: Mr. Lack has returned to network news, a place he is said to be comfortable. But that doesn’t mean he isn’t facing some uncomfortable decisions.
articles.abstract: Mr. Lack has returned to network news, a place he is said to be comfortable. But that doesn’t mean he isn’t facing some uncomfortable decisions.
articles.lead_paragraph: By all appearances, Andrew Lack’s return to the top job at NBC News has gone smoothly.

articles.headline: Global Index May Add Chinese Stocks, Fueling Investment
articles.snippet: MSCI, which compiles the index, says it will work with regulators to assure that China’s markets are prepared for the move.
articles.abstract: MSCI, which compiles the index, says it will work with regulators to assure that China’s markets are prepared for the move.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Chinese stocks do not really need an extra boost. They have tripled in value over the last year to nearly $10 trillion — overtaking Japan, Hong Kong and Britain and coming in second only to the United States.

articles.headline: In Germany, Grass-Roots Opposition to a European-U.S. Trade Deal
articles.snippet: While Germany is one of the countries most likely to benefit from such a deal, polls show that the country has among the strongest public opposition.
articles.abstract: While Germany is one of the countries most likely to benefit from such a deal, polls show that the country has among the strongest public opposition.
articles.lead_paragraph: VERDEN, Germany — Felix Kolb wears socks and sandals, and the occasional hoodie, around the office. It is the uniform of someone working in the countercultural tradition of German political activism but employing the digital tools of contemporary grass-roots movements.

articles.headline: Apple Music and Labels Investigated in 2 States
articles.snippet: The attorneys general of New York and Connecticut are investigating Apple’s negotiations with music companies in search of potential antitrust violations.
articles.abstract: The attorneys general of New York and Connecticut are investigating Apple’s negotiations with music companies in search of potential antitrust violations.
articles.lead_paragraph: While Apple was preparing a splashy introduction for a new service that would stream music over the Internet for a fee, the attorneys general of New York and Connecticut were quietly investigating the Silicon Valley giant’s negotiations with music companies in search of potential antitrust violations.
articles.byline: By Brian X. Chen and Ben Sisario

articles.headline: U.S. Embracing a New Approach on Battling ISIS in Iraq
articles.snippet: The effort to retake Ramadi and push back the Islamic State effectively delays plans to recapture the city of Mosul this year.
articles.abstract: The effort to retake Ramadi and push back the Islamic State effectively delays plans to recapture the city of Mosul this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a major shift of focus in the battle against the Islamic State, the Obama administration is planning to establish a new military base in Anbar Province and send 400 American military trainers to help Iraqi forces retake the city of Ramadi.

articles.headline: Wall St. Courts Start-Ups It Once May Have Ignored
articles.snippet: The titans of finance no longer keep their distance from small tech firms but actively support them as sources of potential tools they once would have developed themselves.
articles.abstract: The titans of finance no longer keep their distance from small tech firms but actively support them as sources of potential tools they once would have developed themselves.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the first day of a hackathon at the Manhattan headquarters of Goldman Sachs, participants from the Wall Street bank showed up in suits. The programmers from Kensho, a start-up that had recently gotten money from Goldman, were there in jeans and ripped shirts.

articles.headline: When Bail Is Out of Defendant’s Reach, Other Costs Mount
articles.snippet: Money bail, entrenched in most jurisdictions, is under new scrutiny, with some critics decrying what they see as racial and financial inequities.
articles.abstract: Money bail, entrenched in most jurisdictions, is under new scrutiny, with some critics decrying what they see as racial and financial inequities.
articles.lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Dominick Torrence, who has lived in this city all his life, has a long rap sheet for dealing drugs but no history of violence. So when he was charged with disorderly conduct and rioting on April 28, a night of unrest after Freddie Gray was fatally injured in police custody, he was shocked to learn the amount he would need to make bail: $250,000, the same amount as two of the officers facing charges over Mr. Gray’s death.

articles.headline: What Apple’s Tim Cook Overlooked in His Defense of Privacy
articles.snippet: When Apple’s chief executive gave a speech on the tech industry’s privacy practices, he failed to fairly explore the benefits of free, ad-supported services.
articles.abstract: When Apple’s chief executive gave a speech on the tech industry’s privacy practices, he failed to fairly explore the benefits of free, ad-supported services.
articles.lead_paragraph: Timothy D. Cook, Apple’s chief executive, delivered a speech last week that raised some eyebrows in the technology industry.

articles.headline: Pope Creates Tribunal for Bishop Negligence in Child Sexual Abuse Cases
articles.snippet: Roman Catholic bishops accused of covering up or failing to prevent the sexual abuse of children by priests will be subject to judgment and discipline by the tribunal.
articles.abstract: Roman Catholic bishops accused of covering up or failing to prevent the sexual abuse of children by priests will be subject to judgment and discipline by the tribunal.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — Pope Francis has approved the creation of a Vatican tribunal for judging bishops accused of covering up or failing to act in cases of child sexual abuse by priests, an unprecedented step long demanded by victims in the more than three decades that the Roman Catholic Church has publicly dealt with the abuse scandal.
articles.byline: By Elisabetta Povoledo and Laurie Goodstein

articles.headline: Increasingly Frequent Call on Baltic Sea: ‘The Russian Navy Is Back’
articles.snippet: Since the conflict in Ukraine began last year, Russian warships have regularly entered a zone where cables are being installed to link Lithuania to Sweden’s electricity grid.
articles.abstract: Since the conflict in Ukraine began last year, Russian warships have regularly entered a zone where cables are being installed to link Lithuania to Sweden’s electricity grid.
articles.lead_paragraph: KLAIPEDA, Lithuania — The Emanuel, a 90-foot trawler, has what is supposed to be a humdrum job, plying a 30-mile stretch of the Baltic Sea to make sure vessels do not snag their anchors on a pair of electricity cables recently installed on the seabed.

articles.headline: Library of Congress Chief Retires Under Fire
articles.snippet: The move comes after the library’s leader, James H. Billington, presided over a series of management and technology failures documented by government watchdog agencies.
articles.abstract: The move comes after the library’s leader, James H. Billington, presided over a series of management and technology failures documented by government watchdog agencies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — James H. Billington, a leading Russia scholar in 1987 when President Ronald Reagan nominated him to be the 13th librarian of Congress, will step down from his post on Jan. 1 after nearly three decades leading the world’s largest library, officials announced Wednesday.
